questions.text: An optical coherence tomography image is given below providing the cross-sectional visualization of the ocular structures. Two of the retinal layers have been marked A and B. Identify the correct direction of transmission of the light and the electrical impulses in the retina respectively.

choices.text: A to B ; A to B
B to A ; A to B
A to B ; B to A
B to A ; B to A

questions.solution:
In the given image, A is the retinal pigment epithelium and B is the nerve fiber layer. The direction of the incident light falling on the retina is from B to A, that is, from the nerve fiber layer towards the retinal pigment epithelium. The direction of transmission of the electrical signals in the retina is from A to B, that is, from the retinal pigment epithelium towards the nerve fiber layer.

The given image shows fovea which indicates the vitreal side of the retina. Hence, B denotes the innermost layer of the retina which is the nerve fiber layer. The pigmented layer on the opposite side denoted by A is the retinal pigment epithelium.

Although the pigment epithelium of the retina is responsible for processing the light signals and converting them to electrical impulses, it is located posteriormost in the retina. The incoming light has to travel through the ganglion cell layer and the bipolar layer to reach the pigment epithelium.

The impulses from the pigment epithelium then travel from the posteriorly placed pigment layer anteriorly towards the bipolar layer and then to the ganglion layer. These impulses are transmitted along the axons of the ganglion cell layer which collectively form the optic nerve.

The arrangement of cells in the retina is shown in the image below:

Related Pearl: Order of neurons in the visual pathway

Order of neurons in the visual pathway

First-order neurons

Photoreceptors
(rods and cones)

Second-order neurons

Bipolar cells

Third-order neurons

Ganglion cells
(optic nerve)

Fourth-order neurons

Axons from the lateral geniculate body
(optic radiation)

 

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

  4. Inner plexiform layer

questions.text: A 60-year-old hypertensive patient, non-compliant with his treatment, suffered an intraparenchymal hemorrhagic stroke one month ago. He undergoes MRI for follow-up. The appearance of the hemorrhage on T1 and T2 weighted MRIs at present, would be respectively?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient had an intraparenchymal stroke one month ago. Hence, the appearance of intraparenchymal hemorrhage on both T1 and T2 weighted MRI is hypointense.

On an MRI, hyperintense refers to a bright or white appearance, while hypointense refers to a darker or black appearance. Isointense means similar color as that of the surrounding brain parenchyma.

The appearance of various stages of intraparenchymal hemorrhage on MRI:

Stage Time Hemoglobin T1 T2
Hyper-acute <24 hours Oxy-hemoglobin Iso Hyper
Acute 1-3 days Deoxy-hemoglobin Iso Hypo
Early subacute 3-7 days Intracellular
Methemoglobin		 Hyper Hypo
Late subacute 7-13 days Extracellular
Methemoglobin		 Hyper Hyper
Chronic >14 days Hemosiderin Hypo Hypo

After 14 days the extracellular blood will be degraded to hemosiderin. Hence, the appearance of the intraparenchymal hemorrhage will be hypointense on both T1 and T2 weighted MRI.

questions.text: A 25-year-old postgraduate student comes to you with an intention to quit smoking. He has tried quitting multiple times in the past but could not control the craving. He recently read about nicotine chewing gums and seeks your advice on quitting smoking and the usage of nicotex. Which of the following is the right advice to give?

choices.text: Chew it just like any regular chewing gum and throw it within 15 minutes
Chew it slowly and keep it pressed on side of mouth till taste fades, then repeat
Nicotine replacement is as good as a placebo and should not be used
Switch to e-cigarette or vaping as it is harmless and free of smoke

questions.solution:
Nicotine gum has to be chewed slowly until there is a taste of nicotine and then kept pressed between the cheek and the teeth. This helps in the absorption of nicotine. This has to be repeated until it releases no more nicotine.

Nicotine withdrawal is characterized by mood changes, insomnia, poor concentration, restlessness, bradycardia, and weight gain. Withdrawal usually peaks at 1-3 days and lasts up to 3-4 weeks. This makes it difficult to maintain abstinence from cigarette smoking. 

Nicotine replacement therapy strategies have been developed to reduce nicotine withdrawal. Therapies include giving nicotine in the form of gums or patches for a period of 1 month to manage the withdrawal symptoms. It can then be gradually tapered.

Nicotine gum is useful in several ways. Firstly, it provides nicotine in low doses to avoid precipitation of withdrawal, which is usually the reason why patients use tobacco again. Secondly, it is free of smoke and other harmful additives. Thirdly, it provides an indirect measure of craving and how heavy tobacco usage was, in the first place.

Other options-

Option A: Chewing it like regular gum releases all of the nicotine at once, causing nausea.

Option C: Nicotine gum acts as a nicotine supplement and is better than a placebo. Any de-addiction requires motivation, and nicotine replacement might serve as a useful adjunct in motivated individuals.

Option D: Vaping or e-cigarettes have adverse effects on the cardiopulmonary system despite no smoke like conventional cigarettes. It consists of a battery-powered device, that converts a nicotine-containing liquid into vapor which the user inhales through the mouth, and exhales, just like a cigarette. It uses vapor instead of smoke, which is why it is referred to as vaping.

questions.text: Which of the following is directly measured by the device shown below?
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a pulse oximeter and it detects pulsatile arterial blood flow. 

It measures the saturation in the peripheral circulatory system. It doesn't measure respiratory rate, cardiac output, blood pressure, tidal volume directly.

Normal saturation should be 95% or more in term newborns to elderly. It is maintained even during anesthesia. Normal PR varies by age,sex, built, activity, etc.

Absence of any signal despite proper application of pulse oximeter may hint towards poor perfusion due to low BP or low cardiac output. 
Moreover, decreased saturation may prompt a checking for inadequate respiration secondary to sedation drugs or lung pathology.

questions.text: A patient with decreased cell counts of all the blood cells was planned for bone marrow examination. Multiple attempts at aspiration failed. Biopsy revealed hypocellular marrow. Which of the following can be a possible cause?
questions.solution:
Fanconi anemia has pancytopenia with a hypocellular marrow.

Causes of dry tap are:

  • Metastatic carcinoma infiltration 
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia 
  • Myelofibrosis 
  • Hairy cell leukemia 
  • Acute leukemia 
  • Lymphomas, Hodgkin’s disease 

Causes of pancytopenia with cellular marrow are:

Primary disease of marrow Secondary to systemic disease
  • Myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal 
    hemoglobinuria (PNH)
  • Myelofibrosis
  • Aleukemic leukemia
  • Myelophthisis
  • Bone marrow lymphoma
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • SLE, sarcoidosis
  • B12, folate deficiency
  • Copper deficiency
  • Hypersplenism
  • Alcohol
  • HIV infection, TB
  • Brucellosis, leishmaniasis

questions.text: A 25-year-old  married lady presents to the OPD  with a clean cut wound on face. She suffered it when her toddler son brazed a sharp object. Sutures are applied after wound dressing. After how many days should the stitches be opened to avoid scar formation on the face?
questions.solution:
Stitches on the face should be opened in 3-5 days. 

If the stitches are kept for a longer period of time than necessary, it may result in scar formation and disfigurement of the face.

The general principle for the time after which sutures should be removed depends on the tension across the wound. More the tension, the more the duration of sutures to be kept.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady with grade 2 osteoarthritis is on treatment with NSAIDs. She developed heartburn and epigastric pain. An upper GI endoscopy revealed gastritis. Which of the following is the most appropriate advice for her pharmacologically?

choices.text: Stop NSAIDs and chew capsule pantoprazole for rapid action
Switch to etoricoxib instead of NSAIDs and use pantoprazole capsule without chewing
Use a combination of antacid and cimetidine for rapid healing
Switch to ranitidine along with sucralfate

questions.solution:
Among the given options, switching to etoricoxib instead of a non-selective COX inhibitor and using pantoprazole without chewing would be the most appropriate advice.

Selective COX2 inhibitors like etoricoxib are less likely to cause gastritis than non-selective COX inhibitors like aspirin or ibuprofen.

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) like pantoprazole are generally coated or available in capsule forms. Without this, it gets degraded by the action of gastric acid. Hence uncrushed PPI should be used 1/2 to 1 hour before the meals.

Other options:

Option A: NSAIDs may be stopped in view of gastric irritation and switched to another analgesic or surgical option might be undertaken. PPI should not be crushed.

Option C: A combination of H2 blockers like cimetidine and antacid should not be administered simultaneously, as the antacids reduce the absorption of all H2 blockers. At least a gap of 2 hours should be maintained.

Option D: Ranitidine increases the gastric pH (i.e. less acidic) which reduces sucralfate efficacy; hence the combination is incorrect. 

Note: Usage of ranitidine for any purpose has been banned by the FDA due to a potential carcinogenic agent in a few batches of this drug.

questions.text: A 25-year-old truck driver presents with fever, chills, headache, and myalgia. He had been prescribed penicillin 1-week ago at a nearby PHC for the treatment of a single indurated non-bleeding genital ulcer as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the likely cause of current symptoms?

choices.text: Resistance of the causative organism to penicillin
Simultaneous common cold due to rhinoviral infection
Spread of the causative organism causing bacteremia
Lysis of causative organism causing release of toxins in blood

questions.solution:
The description and the image of a solitary chancre with red base points towards a diagnosis of syphilis. The headache, fever, and myalgia occurring after the administration of penicillin is known as Jarisch Herxheimer's reaction. The lysis of causative organisms causing the release of toxins in the blood causes this reaction.

Penicillin causes the lysis of the treponemal bacteria leading to the release of toxins in the blood. There is a release of TNF and a probable hypersensitivity reaction. As a result, the above symptoms develop.

Other options:

  • The resistance of syphilis to penicillin is less common. Even if resistance exists, it would not result in the above symptoms.
  • Common cold or rhinovirus infection less often presents with fever. It usually presents a running nose, cough, sore throat, and malaise.
  • Bacteremia in syphilis occurs in later stages of illness and would not present as a flu-like illness in this case.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who has been taking NSAIDs for arthritis for the past 2 years presented to the OPD. He complains of fever, rash, and arthralgia since 1 week. Investigations revealed increased eosinophils in blood and urine, no casts, or crystals in urine. No organism could be cultured from urine. Foley's catheterization was done to monitor the urine output. USG for KUB  revealed the picture as shown below. Kidneys were mildly increased in size. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is acute interstitial nephritis.

Acute interstitial nephritis due to NSAIDs characteristically causes increased eosinophils in blood and urine. The ultrasound image shows maintained corticomedullary differentiation (CMD). Preserved CMD appears as a different echogenicity of cortex and medulla. This finding along with enlarged kidneys makes the diagnosis of acute interstitial nephritis more likely.

Other options:

CKD - Duration of 1 week and enlarged kidney size with preserved corticomedullary differentiation (CMD) makes this unlikely. 

Urethral obstruction - Successful foley catheterization rules out urethral obstruction

ATN - An absence of casts or crystals which are usually seen in ATN are absent in this case. 

In a patient with renal disease, we first try to ascertain if it is acute or chronic. Then the management is decided based on the nature of the renal disease which could be pre-renal, renal, or post-renal:

  Parameter AKI CKD
1 Duration Around 7 days More than 3 months
2 Size Normal or enlarged Shrunken 
3 Corticomedullary
differentiation		 Preserved Lost
4 Complications of CKD Absent  Present

questions.text: A preterm baby is brought with symptoms of abdominal distention and hematochezia. The abdominal x-ray shows a portal vein gas shadow. The child's condition is classified as Modified Bell's stage IIIa, which of the following findings is likely to be seen?

choices.text: Modified Bell's Stage IIIa NEC has radiological findings only

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in the preterm baby is suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). In a child with Modified Bell's Stage IIIA NEC, signs of generalized peritonitis like abdomen with guarding and rigidity would be present. 

Modified Bell's Staging Criteria:

Stage I - Suspected NEC
Stage II - Proven NEC
Stage III - Advanced NEC

Stage   Intestinal signs Systemic signs Radiological signs
IA Suspected NEC Mild abdominal distention, emesis, guaiac-positive stool Temperature instability, apnea, bradycardia, lethargy Normal or intestinal dilatation, mild ileus
IB   IA + Bright red blood from the rectum Same as IA Same as IA
IIA Mildly ill Absent bowel sounds Same as IA  Pneumatosis intestinalis, ileus
IIB Moderately ill  IIA + definite abdominal tenderness IA+ Metabolic acidosis and thrombocytopenia   IIA + portal venous gas, with or without ascites
IIIA Severely ill, bowel intact  IIB + peritonitis with marked tenderness, and abdominal distension  IIB+ hypotension, bradycardia, acidosis, DIC, neutropenia  IIB + definite ascites 
IIIB Severely ill, bowel
perforated		  Same as III A Same as IIIA   IIB +pneumoperitoneum

Necrotizing enterocolitis:

It is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in the newborn period. It is characterized by various degrees of mucosal or transmural inflammation and necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. 

Three major risk factors implicated are:

  • Prematurity is the greatest risk factor
  • Formula feeding
  • Bacterial colonization of the intestine

Incidence and mortality increase with decreasing birth weight and gestational age. It usually presents within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal X-ray. The important signs are :

  • Pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall) is diagnostic. It corresponds to stage IIA.
  • Portal vein gas is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB.
  • Pneumoperitoneum indicates perforation and corresponds to stage IIIB.

Management of NEC includes supportive measures - nil per oral, nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication for surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk. Prebiotics and synbiotics can be used with variable efficacy in the use of probiotics.

The given X-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows). It is seen as a characteristic train-track lucency appearance within the bowel wall due to the gas produced by bacteria.

questions.text:
A known type 1 diabetic patient presented to the emergency with abdominal pain, vomiting, and nausea. He reports having missed his insulin dose. DKA is suspected in him. So an ABG is taken and a fluid infusion is started. Insulin administration is not given until ABG reports are available. What could be the possible reason for delaying insulin?

DKA: Diabetic ketoacidosis

ABG: Arterial blood gas analysis

choices.text: Insulin alters the values in ABG analysis

questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards a likely diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) that could be associated with hypokalemia. Insulin causes potassium uptake by activating Na-K+ ATPases which may worsen hypokalemia.

DKA is an acute, severe, hyperglycemic disorder, which was considered a hallmark of type 1 diabetes, but can occur in type 2 diabetes as well. Inadequate administration of insulin (especially during times of physiologic stress like infections) may precipitate DKA.

Features of DKA include:

  • Nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain
  • Hypotension and tachycardia
  • Hyperglycemia, glycosuria, and ketosis
  • High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA)

As a physiologic response to acidosis, the body loses potassium and there is total body potassium deficit. Serum potassium might be normal or elevated, despite total body potassium deficit.

The initial treatment in DKA is fluid administration (first normal saline, then half-normal saline, then dextrose+ half- normal saline). Insulin has to be given once potassium status is known. If insulin is administered prior to potassium correction, it would worsen the preexisting hypokalemia.

Management for DKA is as follows:

questions.text: What is the type of joint found in the manubriosternum?
questions.solution:
The Manubriosternal joint is a secondary cartilaginous joint. 

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

  • Synarthrosis - structures are connected by a fibrous band of tissue. Example: 1st sternocostal joint
  • Synchondrosis/primary cartilaginous joints. Example: costochondral joints
  • Symphysis/secondary cartilaginous joints. Example: Manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints 
  • Synovial joints - the presence of these helps the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:
    • Interchondral joint
    • Sternocostal joint
    • Costovertebral joint
    • Costotransverse joint

Secondary cartilaginous joints are characterized by the presence of a fibrocartilaginous disc that connects the articular surfaces, which are covered by a thin layer of hyaline cartilage. These joints are considered permanent. Examples of secondary cartilaginous joints include the symphysis pubis, the manubriosternal joint, and the intervertebral joints between the vertebral bodies.

Synchondrosis refers to the primary cartilaginous joints in which the advancing areas of ossification are separated by hyaline cartilage. They are temporary joints and are associated with growth. Hyaline cartilage has the ability to ossify with age, thus making these joints undergo synostosis once the growth is complete. An example of this type of joint is the epiphyseal plate. 

Synarthrosis - structures are connected by a fibrous band of tissue. E.g, 1st sternocostal joint

Syndesmosis refers to a type of joint where bones are connected by true fibrous tissue. In some cases, this connection is established through an interosseous ligament, as seen in the tibiofibular syndesmosis and radioulnar syndesmosis. In other instances, the connection is formed by a dense fibrous membrane, particularly in the posterior region of the sacroiliac joint.

questions.text: A left-handed patient suffering from refractory epilepsy is planned for surgery. Pre-operative wada testing with a carotid injection of sodium barbital amytal was positive on the left side. Which of the following represents the language areas in this patient to be preserved during surgery?
questions.solution:
F, J represents the Broca's area (inferior frontal gyrus) and Wernicke's area (superior temporal gyrus) that to be preserved during epilepsy surgery.

In right-handed people, the dominant hemisphere (controlling speech and memory localization) is located on the left side in 95% of cases. But in left-handed people, the dominant hemisphere lies on right side only in 70% of people.

Wada test is a presurgical test to determine the actual side of the language areas in the patient. It consists of administering short-acting sodium amobarbital via the carotid artery. There is transient hemiplegia on the opposite side which resolves in a few minutes as the drug is cleared.

While the patient is under the effect of this anesthetic, a neurologist examines the memory and language function of the brain, to ascertain the localization of areas. If language impairment occurs on the side of injection, that is the dominant side. In this case it was positive on left side, hence this person has left hemisphere dominant- consists of language areas.

This test was named after Dr. Juhin Wada, a Japanese born neurologist. It has been largely replaced by the advent of fMRI and MEG and reserved only for doubtful cases of ambidextrous or left-handed individuals.

Other options do not point towards the location of language areas.

questions.text: You are a microbiologist researching for a newer diagnostic test to detect coronavirus in the recent SARS-COV2 pandemic. A test to detect which of the following need not be developed for this virus?
questions.solution:
A diagnostic test to detect DNA is not needed for coronavirus as it doesn't have a DNA molecule at its core. It is an RNA virus.

Coronavirus is a single-stranded linear RNA virus with helical symmetry and an envelope.

The testing strategy for coronavirus is as below:

  rtPCR IgM IgG Significance
1 + - - Window period
2 + + - Early phase 
3 + + + Active phase
4 + - + Late or recurrent
5 - + - Early infection with false-negative PCR
6 - + + Recovery phase
7 - - + Recovered past infection

CDC or FDA does not support antibody testing for any infection. These may be used for epidemiologic purposes to predict infection trends. 

Coronavirus testing currently involves the detection of viral antigens or nucleic acids.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to you with fever and cough with expectoration. On examination, his vitals were as follows: PR- 110/min, RR- 24/min, SpO2- 91%, T- 104 F. His radiograph is as shown below. Which of the following findings would be seen on clinical examination of his respiratory system?

choices.text: Vesicular breath sounds, increased vocal resonance and tactile fremitus
Bronchial breath sounds, increased vocal resonance and tactile fremitus
Vesicular breath sounds, decreased vocal resonance and tactile fremitus
Bronchial breath sounds, decreased vocal resonance and tactile fremitus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest x-ray showing a consolidation in the right lower lobe is suggestive of a likely diagnosis of pneumonia. The patient is likely to have bronchial breath sounds with increased vocal resonance and tactile fremitus.

In a healthy lung, the sound of air passing through the airways gets muffled as it goes from the upper airways with a wide luminal cross-section to the lower-airways with a narrower luminal cross-section. This produces the 'normal vesicular' breath sounds heard on auscultation. In a consolidated or fibrosed lung, which becomes more dense than air-filled, the sound of air in the distal airways getting better conducted through the diseased lung parenchyma. As a result, on auscultation, a louder sound is heard, similar to what would be heard in the bronchi or proximal airways, hence the term 'bronchial' breath sounds is used.

The same principle applies to the conduction of vocally produced sound, ie, normally it is muffled in a healthy lung but it is better conducted in a consolidated lung and hence the patient also has an increased vocal resonance and increased tactile vocal fremitus.

Breath sounds and vocal resonance would both be decreased in conditions where the conduction of air through the chest wall is impaired, such as due to the presence of air or fluid as in pneumothorax and pleural effusion respectively, or in the case of a collapsed lung.

questions.text: A pregnant lady attends her routine ANC check-up. She complains of burning micturition and fever. A urine microscopy examination revealed the presence of gram-negative bacilli in acidic urine. Cultures revealed a colony count of 10^5/ml of urine. The organism was isolated and found to be indole positive. The likely causative organism is?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms and the microbial features, that is, gram-negative, indole positive, and the colony count suggest urinary tract infection due to the causative organism E. coli.

UTI may be asymptomatic or present with clinical features depending on the site of localization. Lower UTI generally presents as fever, chills, burning micturition, while upper UTI presents as flank pain, with renal angle tenderness.

The growth of organisms from aseptically collected urine samples in significant numbers makes the diagnosis of UTI. Classically, the growth of 10^5 CFU/ml of urine is considered significant. But recent data show that values more than or equal to 10²/ml in females and 10³/ml in males appears to be more sensitive in patients presenting with symptoms of cystitis.

Other options are unlikely due to the following features:

Amongst the given options, only E. coli is indole positive, ruling out P.mirabilis, enterobacter, and klebsiella.

Proteus, klebsiella, ureaplasma is urea splitting organisms and cause the urine to be alkaline. Hence, acidic urine rules out these organisms.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in NICU. The consultant asks you to monitor the pre and post ductal SpO2 readings for a baby with cyanotic heart disease. The conventional way of measuring pre and post-ductal saturation(SpO2) respectively is?

choices.text: Both measured from the right hand before and after giving oxygen for 10 minutes

questions.solution:
The site for measuring preductal and post ductal SpO2 readings has to be hand and foot respectively. The conventional way is to use the right hand and one of the feet. 

The pre-ductal SpO2 essentially implies measuring saturation before ductus arteriosus joins and post-ductal implies measuring saturation after ductus arteriosus joins aorta. This is so because, if ductus arteriosus is patent, it allows the mixing of de-oxygenated blood causing a fall in oxygen saturation measured distal to the mixing site.

 The ductus arteriosus is generally attached after the left subclavian branches out. Hence measuring saturation from hands (supplied by subclavian artery on either side) and feet (supplied by branches and continuation of abdominal aorta) should be done.

The difference in the saturation of more than 10% conveys the significant right to left shunt.

questions.text: A drug trial compares the effect of a drug compared to placebo in decreasing cholesterol levels in 2 groups of 500 individuals each. A side effect to be studied simultaneously is the elevation of creatine kinase due to rhabdomyolysis. 10 individuals who received the drug develop this side effect, while only 5 individuals who are on placebo have this side effect. Calculate the number needed to harm (NNH).
questions.solution:
The number needed to harm (NNH) for this particular drug is 100.

The number needed to harm is given as the number of individuals we need to treat, to encounter an effect or side-effect of a particular drug. The higher the NNH, the better is the drug.

For example, if we see a side effect of a drug in 1 out of every 100 patients we are treating, it is better as compared to encountering 1 side effect after treating 10 patients.

The NNH to harm is 100 and 10 respectively in these cases, and the former drug is better because it has lesser side effects.

NNH is calculated as 1/absoulte risk increase (i.e. 1/ARI).

Step1: Calculate the risk of side effects with the drug as well as placebo

The risk with drug = 10/500

The risk with placebo = 5 /500

Step 2: Calculate the absolute risk increase:  ARI= side effect with drug-side effect even with placebo

10/500 - 5/500 = 5/500 = 1/100 = 0.01

Step 3: Calculate the NNH

1/ARI = 1/0.01 = 100

questions.text: While collecting samples from a patient scheduled to undergo a blood transfusion, which of the following vacutainers will you use to collect blood for cross-matching, and which cannula will you use for blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Lavender/purple vacutainer (EDTA) vacutainer is used for routine hematological studies and green cannula (18G) is used for blood transfusion.

EDTA is the additive present in purple vacutainer, which chelates calcium and other metal ions needed for the coagulation cascade. It is routinely used for most routine hematological investigations because it preserves the morphology of cellular components.

Though green cannula(18G) can be used for blood transfusion. Grey (16G) is preferred in case multiple transfusion or rapid fluid infusion is necessary.

Cap colour Additive present
Light blue top Sodium citrate
Dark green top Heparin
Purple top EDTA
Pale yellow top Acid citrate dextrose
Light grey top Sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae

Size Color Coding Flow Rate Uses
14G Orange 270ml/min Trauma Patients, Rapid, Large Volume replacement
16G Grey 236ml/min Trauma Patients, Major Surgery, Intra Partum/Post Partum, GI bleeds, Multiple blood transfers, High volume of Fluids

questions.text: A 55-year-old locomotive operator presents with complaints of worm-like swelling over his right leg. During clinical examination, a Brodie Trendelenburg test is performed. Which of the following statements is false regarding the test?

choices.text: A tourniquet can be used for occluding the saphenofemoral junction
Rapid filling  from above indicates saphenofemoral incompetence
Gradual filling  from below upwards indicates saphenopopliteal incompetence
Positive Brodie Trendelenburg test indicates a need for surgery

questions.solution:
The gradual filling of veins from below upwards indicates the perforator incompetence. Brodie Trendelenberg test is performed to test for the incompetence of the saphenofemoral valve and the communicating system.

1. Trendelenburg’s test - Lay the patient down and elevate the leg. Empty the vessels and tie a tourniquet below the SFJ. Ask the patient to stand up:

  • Trendelenburg’s test part ll - Here the tourniquet is not released. A gradual filling from below to upwards indicates perforator incompetence.
  • Trendelenburg’s test part l - Here the tourniquet is released. A rapid filling from above shows the saphenofemoral incompetence.

2. Morrisey’s cough impulse: the patient is asked to cough. A cough impulse at the saphenofemoral junction indicates SFJ incompetence.

3. Schwartz test: If a thrill is felt at SFJ on tapping over the incompetent vein, indicates SFJ incompetence.

4. Modified Perthes test: A tourniquet is tied below SFJ and the patient is asked to walk. An increase in pain and prominence of dilated veins indicate DVT.

5. Fegan’s method - Mark the places of excessive bulges within the varicosities. Ask the patient to lie down and empty the varicose vessels. Palpate along the marked area to look for gaps and pits in the deep fascia, which indicates perforator incompetence.

questions.text: A 50-year-old obese smoker presents with heartburn and epigastric pain. The gastroenterologist performs an endoscopic biopsy and confirms the diagnosis of Barrett's esophagus. The endoscopic appearance of the affected mucosa before and after the application of Lugol's iodine is?
questions.solution:
The affected mucosa in Barrett's esophagus is velvety red on gross or endoscopic examination and pale white after the application of lugol's iodine.

In contrast, the normal esophageal mucosa is glossy and pale which becomes dark brown due to glycogen content after application of lugol's iodine.

Normal stomach mucosa is light brown on gross examination.

questions.text: A patient comes with a complaint of vertigo in a certain head position. She denies any ear fullness or hearing loss. A Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis and an Epley's maneuver is performed to treat her condition. The symptoms are relieved due to the repositioning of otoconial debris from?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with vertigo and a positive Dix-Hallpike test is suggestive of benign positional paroxysmal vertigo (BPPV). The otoconial debris are repositioned from the posterior semicircular canal to the utricle to relieve the symptoms of BPPV.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. 

A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. It is due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle. The patient complains of vertigo on moving or tilting the head to the affected side. In up to 90 percent of the patients, it can be relieved by administering a therapeutic Epley's maneuver on the affected side.

The Epley's maneuver consists of five positions:

  Head and neck Body position
Position 1 Head turned 45°  to lie down in a head-hanging position
Position 2 Head turned with
affected ear up		 -
Position 3 The whole body and head rotated away from the affected ear in a face-down position  
Position 4 Head still turned to unaffected side by 45° Brought to sitting position
Position 5 Head turned forward with chin brought down 20° -

questions.text: A surgeon uses the given instrument to visualize the lower alimentary tract for tumors in an elderly male. What structures can he visualize?
questions.solution:
The anal canal and lower rectum can be visualised.

A conventional proctoscope can visualize a lesion up to 10-15 cm from the anal verge.

A surgeon uses a lubricated proctoscope to visualize lesions in the anus, anorectal junction, and lower rectum. It is done as an OPD procedure to detect haemorrhoids, polyps, or ulcers. A biopsy may be taken if it is above the anoderm. It is avoided in anal fissures as it causes undue pain.

questions.text: Thyroxine stimulating hormone is elevated in hypothyroidism.  A new test is employed and results are being interpreted from a hilly city and a coastal city to detect elevated TSH levels due to hypothyroidism. Which of the following is true regarding the test?

choices.text: If a person from hilly city tests positive, he is more likely to actually to have hypothyroidism, than someone who tests positive from coastal city
If a person from hilly city tests negative , he is less likely to have hypothyroidism, than someone who tests negative  from coastal city
A person having  hypothyroidism is likely to test positive in hilly city than coastal city
A person not having  hypothyroidism is likely to test negative in hilly city than coastal city

questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is more prevalent in hilly areas than in coastal areas. If someone from a hilly city tests positive he is more likely to have the disease than someone who tests positive in a coastal area.

Positive predictive value (PPV) increases with an increase in prevalence. It refers to the chances of having the disease if the test turns out to be positive.

Similarly, if someone tests negative coastal area, he is more likely to not have hypothyroidism, than someone who tests negative in a hilly area.

These results can be interpreted with an analogy of malaria being more prevalent in India than in the UK. If a person tests malaria positive in India, he is more likely to actually have the disease, than being testes positive by chance. Similarly, if a person tests malaria negative in the UK, that is because he might not have the disease. Whilst we might still think of the person having malaria, and being tested negative by chance. Thus, just tested positive or negative doesn't hold a significance, it has to be interpreted in terms of how common the disease is, in that particular area.

The other options of having the disease and testing positive depend on the sensitivity of the test, not on the prevalence of the disease.

Whilst not having the disease and testing negative depends on the specificity of the test, not on the prevalence of the disease.

questions.text: A 1st year DNB cardiothoracic surgeon is assisting his consultant for a beating heart transplant surgery. It involves ligating the major vessels one by one and taking out the heart. The donor's heart is then transplanted in the body, while a heart-lung machine pumps the blood. Select the correct pericardial sinus into which the consultant places his finger, to separate the arteries and veins.
questions.solution:
The pericardial sinus that separates the arteries and the veins are the transverse pericardial sinus.

It lies posterior to the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk and anterior to the superior vena cava.

Other options:

The oblique pericardial sinus lies posterior to the left atrium and is formed by the reflection of the pericardium.

Posterior aortic sinus is one of the three pouches formed on the inside of the cusps of the aortic semilunar valve in the ascending aorta. The right and left aortic sinus give origin to the coronary arteries.

The coronary sulcus is the external sulci circling the surface of the heart, separating the atria and the ventricles. It contains the right coronary artery, the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery, and coronary sinus.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in medicine OPD. A 58-year-old man comes with palpable organomegaly till below the umbilicus (corresponding to level 5 in the given image). Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of the given finding?
questions.solution:
The given finding corresponds to massive splenomegaly. Typhoid does not cause massive splenomegaly. It may cause mild-moderate splenomegaly.

Massive splenomegaly is defined as spleen palpable 8 cm below the costal margin or weighing 1000gm. Some authors even classify it to be massive if it extends till umbilicus or further.

Causes of massive splenomegaly include:

  • Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • Gaucher’s disease
  • Lymphomas
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Myelofibrosis with myeloid metaplasia
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Polycythemia vera
  • Diffuse splenic hemangiomatosis

questions.text: You are a recently graduated MBBS doctor serving bond as a physician in a rural area where there is no availability of surgeon. A middle-aged man presented to you with jaundice. You do the physical examination and necessary investigations. Presence of which of the finding points towards a diagnosis that doesn't need a surgical referral?

choices.text: Acute onset right upper quadrant pain
Increased AST: ALT ratio with normal INR

questions.solution:
The presence of increased AST: ALT ratio (AST>ALT) with normal INR is suggestive of alcoholic hepatitis and it does not need a surgical referral and can be managed by a physician.

Only when the liver is cirrhotic, it might need a surgical referral. In that case, the INR would be invariably elevated then due to poor liver function.

Other options:

Pale stools, pruritus at nighttime, and an increase in ALP which is disproportionate to ALT or AST are well-known features of cholestatic jaundice. It would need a surgical referral to relieve the cause of obstruction.

Acute onset right upper quadrant pain associated with chills is seen in choledocholithiasis which again needs a surgical referral.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male, who is a known case of PVD, comes with complaints of rest pain. Which of the following values of ankle and brachial pressure correspond to the values that can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
An ABPI of <0.5 is associated with rest pain. The ABPI of 0.4, seen in case of option D, Ankle - 48/36mm Hg, Brachial - 120/80mm Hg, will be corresponding to that of rest pain.

ABPI = Systolic Pressure at Ankle/ Systolic Pressure in the arm(Brachial)

=48/120 = 0.4

 

Other options:

A - ABPI =1.25

B - ABPI = 1

C - ABPI = 0.75

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a classic triad of flank pain, left flank mass, and hematuria. A renal biopsy is planned to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is incorrect with respect to the boundaries of the left kidney?

choices.text: The upper border of morrison's parallelogram passes through T11
The lower border of Morrison's parallelogram passes through L3
The renal angle overlies the upper border of the kidney
The renal angle is bound by the 12th rib and erector spinae

questions.solution:
The renal angle overlies the lower border of the kidney.

The given clinical scenario points towards a likely diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. A biopsy is done to confirm or refute the diagnosis. Although, blind biopsy has mostly been replaced by a USG/CT guided biopsy. Knowing the relations of the kidney may be helpful in doing a renal biopsy. 

Morrison's parallelogram is marked by 2 horizontal lines passing through T11 and L3. Kidneys lie in this parallelogram when approached from the back, hence, helpful in surface marking for renal biopsy.

The renal angle is bound by the 12th rib and erector spinae and it overlies the lower border of the kidney.

questions.text: As a 1st-year resident surgeon, you are operating on a 30-year-old patient with unilateral cystic scrotal swelling which is brilliantly transilluminating. Which of the following should be done?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings are suggestive of hydrocele.

Eversion of the sac upon itself is known as Jaboulay's procedure and should be done in this case of hydrocele.

A hydrocele is due to fluid accumulation between the 2 layers of tunica vaginalis. It may be primary or secondary, depending on whether it is due to defective absorption or excess formation. Eversion of the sac causes the production of fluid towards the outside, which can be absorbed by outer scrotal layers.

The other method of treating the hydrocele is plicating the redundant tunica, which can be done when the sac wall is thin. This is known as the Lord's operation.

Other options:

Option A: Excision of the sac is not recommended as it is liable to bleed and cause a scrotal hematoma.

Option C: Ligation of the scrotal vein will impair venous drainage and result in ischemia or oedema.

Option D: Percutaneous drainage of fluid is not a long-term solution as the fluid will reappear within a week. 

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have an intracardiac thrombus and was scheduled for a transesophageal echocardiography. Which chamber of the heart is closest to the probe during this procedure?
questions.solution:
The left atrium is closest to the esophagus, separated only by the pericardium. Hence, it would be the chamber closest to the transesophageal probe.

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the test of choice for prosthetic valve vegetation, intracardiac thrombi, and left atrial appendage.

Since TEE has to penetrate fewer structures (chest wall, ribs, etc.), a higher frequency probe can be used, giving better resolution images than transthoracic echocardiography.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female has come for her annual well-woman checkup. During the breast examination, the following finding is noted. Which of the following is true regarding this finding?

choices.text: It is usually seen in benign inflammatory breast conditions
It is due to blockage of subcuticular lymphatics
It is due to Thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast

questions.solution:
The image shows the Peau d'Orange appearance, a classical sign of breast carcinoma. It is due to the blockage of subcuticular lymphatics. The resultant edema deepens the mouth of the sweat glands and hair follicles giving rise to the typical orange peel appearance. 

Other options:-

  • It is not necessarily always associated with nipple retraction, as seen in the image above where there is peau de orange, but no nipple retraction.
  • Peau d'Orange appearance is a classical sign of breast carcinoma not a finding of benign inflammatory breast condition.
  • Thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast is called Mondor’s disease. The pathognomic feature of Mondor's Disease is a thrombosed subcutaneous cord, attached to the skin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old vegetarian man weighing 72 kg came to a screening camp for a routine health check-up. He has a family history of kidney disease and insists on getting kidney function tests done. His plasma creatinine value turns out to be 2 mg/dL. Estimated values for creatinine clearance for this patient using the Cockroft Gault equation are?
questions.solution:
The estimated creatinine clearance values for this patient are 50 ml/min.

Cockroft gault equation is given as [140- age(in years) x body weight (in kg)] x 0.85(if female) / 72 x Plasma creatinine (mg/dL)

Substituting the values for this patient CrCl = (140 - 40) x 72 / 72 x 2 = 100 x 72 / 72 x 2 = 50 ml/min.

Creatinine is useful for the estimation of GFR because it a small, freely filtered solute that is not reabsorbed by tubules. This patient has a low creatinine clearance value and will correlate with low GFR values.

However, its values may increase due to dietary ingestion of cooked meat and maybe secreted into tubules via an organic cation pathway in end-stage renal disease leading to false low or high values. As this person is vegetarian, calculated values will more or less accurate.

questions.text: A patient with stroke came to your OPD. His neurological examination revealed the following finding. Which of the following is a true statement regarding the examination finding?

choices.text: It is non-rhythmic, non-voluntary muscular contraction
It is due to increased gamma motor neuron activity
It is due to decreased alpha neuron activity
It is a result of lower motor neuron type palsy

questions.solution:
Clonus is due to sustained hyperactivity of alpha and gamma motor neurons.

Clonus is defined as regular, rhythmic, repetitive involuntary (Option A) muscle contractions of the part of a limb (ankle, patella) when abrupt sustained muscle stretch is given. When the clonus is sustained for 5 or more beats, it is considered to abnormal.

Normally during flexion of the ankle, reflex extensor stimulation is inhibited by Renshaw cells. These cells are inhibitory interneurons that receive excitatory input from cortical fibers and lead to the inhibition of alpha and gamma motor neurons. Thus clonus is seen in upper motor neuron-type palsy (Option D) which removes the inhibitory cortical control, allows hyperactivity of alpha (Option C) and gamma neurons , and causes contraction of the ankle flexors and extensors in sequence. Management includes treatment of the underlying cause along with physical therapy.

questions.text: A potter named Rakesh visited a neurology camp organized in his locality. The intern performing the examination found normal sensory examination when tested in both the hands individually. Then he was asked to close his eyes and identify which hand was touched with the cotton wisp. The intern tested both hands simultaneously, but he was able to locate it on only one hand. The lesion is located in?

choices.text: Dorsal column level before crossing in medulla
Dorsal column level after crossing in medulla

questions.solution:
The intern performed bilateral simultaneous testing for touch sensation. Unable to identify or localize the stimulus points towards a lesion in the contralateral parietal lobe.

Bilateral simultaneous stimulation tests the ability of the parietal lobe to integrate the sensation. It is hence called cortical sensation.

When testing each hand individually with eyes open, the cortex just has to localize the individual stimulus, which it can easily do with an intact sensory pathway.

Whilst doing it simultaneously on both hands, the parietal cortex of both sides will be stimulated and the patient would ideally be able to pay attention to both of them equally. But, in the lesion of the association cortex (located in the parietal lobe for touch sensation), the patient is unable to pay equal attention to both the stimuli. Hence the brain ignores/neglects the stimuli corresponding to the lesioned side of the brain. 

Other options:

Receptor level lesion would make the subject unable to identify the particular sensation at all. As Rakesh could identify the stimulus when tested in individual hands, this is unlikely.

Dorsal column lesion would affect the sensation in the same or opposite side if it is involved before or after crossing in the medulla respectively. Again, the test for individual hands would have been abnormal.

questions.text: A 2nd year PG is assisting in the cesarian section for a multiparous woman. Tubal sterilization is planned in the same setting. Identify the correct location of the structure she should ligate?
questions.solution:
The structure that needs to be ligated for tubal sterilization is the fallopian tube which is a content of the broad ligament lying along its superior border. It corresponds with the structure marked B in the given image.

There are different modifications as to how ligation is carried out and which part is ligated. 

Technique Procedure Remark
Pomeroy Mid-segment of the fallopian tube formed into a loop,
tied at the base and excised		 Small incision 
Irving Mid-segment of the fallopian tube ligated and
intervening portion excised.
Proximal end buried in the myometrium
Distal end buried in the broad ligament		 Laparoscopically done
Uchida Serosa of the mid-segment of the fallopian tube
stripped off the muscular layer, then excised.
Proximal end buried in the myometrium.		 Excellent reversibility
Kroener The distal end of the fallopian tube ligated and excised
(Fimbriectomy)		  

Other structures at the superior end of broad ligament include:

  • A - Anterior - Round ligament from the uterus to labia majora
  • C - Posterior - Ovarian ligament from the ovary to the uterus

Related Pearl: Contents of the Broad ligament

  • One tube - Fallopian tube
  • Two ligaments:
    • Round ligament of uterus
    • Ovarian ligament
  • Two arteries:
    • Uterine artery
    • Ovarian artery
  • Two nerve plexus:
    • Uterovaginal plexus
    • Ovarian plexus
  • Three embryological remnants:
    • Epoophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Paroophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Gartner’s duct (Wolffian duct)
  • Other structures:
    • Lymph vessels and lymph nodes
    • Fibrous connective tissue

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is diagnosed to be sputum smear-positive for Tuberculosis. Based on further examination, a diagnosis of Right-sided tubercular pleural effusion is made. Which of the following clinical examination findings is not consistent with a diagnosis of right-sided pleural effusion?

choices.text: Stony dull percussion note on the right side
Mediastinal shift to the right side
Tracheal deviation to the left side
Increased vocal resonance above the level of effusion

questions.solution:
A mediastinal shift to the left side is expected in the case of a right-sided pleural effusion. 

Clinical findings in pleural effusion:

  • A mediastinal shift to the opposite side
  • Stony dull percussion note over the region of effusion
  • Diminished or absent breath sounds (tubular above level of effusion)
  • Reduced or absent vocal resonance (increased above level effusion)
  • Pleural rub may be heard above the level of effusion
  • Tracheal deviation to the opposite side in case of large effusions

A similar set of findings is seen in the case of empyema as well.

The tracheal shift to the same side in the presence of pleural effusion can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Mesothelioma
  • Empyema or effusion following pre-existing fibrosis
  • Mass with collapse and pleural effusion.

questions.text: A mother comes with a complaint of muscle weakness. The doctor suspects a genetic disease as both her kids have muscle weakness, which is more severe. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the mitochondria of 50% of cells. While similar testing for her children reveals a mutation in 100% of cells. A pedigree is shown below. Select the correct statement with regard to this.
questions.solution:
The given scenario and pedigree points towards a mitochondrial disease with variable severity in offsprings. It is due to heteroplasmy.

Clues to diagnosis - disease passed only from mother to offsprings and a mutation in mitochondrial DNA sequencing confirms the diagnosis.

A mitochondrion may contain up to thousands of copies of mitochondrial DNA with only a few of them being mutated. This is called heteroplasmy. A defect may arise only after a certain number of copies are mutated. This is called the threshold effect. When the mother cell passes mitochondria to the children, it is highly variable, as to how many mutated copies each child receives. As a result, the symptoms of the mitochondrial disorder are highly variable in severity from person to person.

Other options:

  • Anticipation: The clinical features become increasingly severe in successive generations. Classically seen in trinucleotide repeat diseases (Huntington chorea)
  • Variable expressivity: Similar genotype but varying phenotype. As seen in varying severity of disease with NF1 mutation (neurofibromatosis).
  • Genetic heterogeneity: Mutations at several different loci producing the same trait.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady visited a psychiatrist with complaints of excessive fear of closed spaces. She avoids using an elevator or closing her washroom door. A medication with which of the following mechanism of action will be given for the long-term management of the condition that this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of the phobic disorder. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are the preferred drugs in treating phobic disorders.

Phobia can be described as the fear that is irrational and out of proportion to the stimulus. Common types of phobia include:

  • Agoraphobia - Fear of unfamiliar places from which escape is difficult
  • Claustrophobia - Fear of closed spaces
  • Acrophobia - Fear of heights.

Behavioral therapy is the treatment of choice. Among the pharmacological therapies, benzodiazepines may be used for acute relief, while the SSRIs are preferred for long term treatment.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
1. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker presented to you with a history of pain in the calf muscles while walking, which is relieved on taking rest. He also complains of the darkening of his foot in the past 6 months. His ankle-brachial index is measured to be 0.7. The consultant asks you to examine the peripheral pulses in both lower limbs in the artery that begins between the two malleoli. Which of the following is an incorrect relation of this artery?

choices.text: Laterally - first tendon of extensor digitorum longus
Superficially - skin, fascia and inferior extensor retinaculum

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the artery that is to be examined is the dorsalis pedis artery. The deep relation is not extensor hallucis brevis (EHB). EHB lies superficial to the artery.

The dorsalis pedis artery is the continuation of the anterior tibial artery on the dorsum of the foot. It begins between the two malleoli and runs on the medial side of the dorsum till the 1st intermetatarsal space and ends by completing the plantar arch. The structures related to this artery are:

  • Superficial relation - Skin, fascia, inferior extensor retinaculum, EHB which crosses from the lateral to the medial side.
  • Medial relation - Extensor hallucis longus
  • Lateral relation - First tendon of Extensor digitorum longus
  • Deep relation - Capsular ligament of ankle joint. Talus, navicular, and intermediate cuneiform bones

The ratio of the ankle and brachial artery pressures is termed the ankle: brachial index or ABI. The normal ABI is >1.40.

Normally, systolic blood pressure in the legs and arms is similar. Ankle pressure may be slightly higher than arm pressure due to pulse-wave amplification.

In the presence of hemodynamically significant stenoses, the systolic blood pressure in the leg is decreased.

Ankle-brachial index (ABI):

1-1.40 Normal
0.91-0.99 Borderline
≤0.90 Abnormal
0.5-0.8 Symptoms of leg claudication
<0.5 Critical limb ischemia
>1.40 Indicates noncompressible artery

questions.text: Which of the following represents Casal's necklace due to niacin deficiency?
questions.solution:
The image labelled as C shows Casal's necklace which is characteristic of niacin deficiency.

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra which presents with a triad of diarrhoea, dermatitis, and dementia. Dermatitis is due to the accumulation of kynurenic acid and resembles a sunburn, as hyperpigmentation and scaly plaques are seen in photo-exposed areas. These patients may also have other nutritional deficiencies causing other skin lesions simultaneously. 

Pellagra-like symptoms are also known to be caused by the deficiency of tryptophan, and micronutrients required for conversion of tryptophan to niacin (iron, riboflavin (vitamin B2), pyridoxine (vitamin B6)). It can also be seen in alcoholics. The antitubercular drug isoniazid is a structural analogue of niacin and can precipitate pellagra.

Symptoms of pellagra -

  • Bright red glossitis followed by characteristic scaling and pigmentation of the skin that is exposed to the sun
  • Diarrhoea
  • Depression
  • Dementia
  • Seizures

Pellagra can be fatal if not treated promptly.

It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone.

It is treated by oral supplementation of 100–200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for 5 days.

Other options -

Image A- Burn contracture

Image B- Maculopapular rash 

Image D- Allergic contact dermatitis due to cloth dye. It shows erythema, edema and vesicular lesions which are not seen in pellagra dermatitis.

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Pellagra-like Symptoms

Condition/Disease

Reason for niacin deficiency

Hartnup disease

Intestinal & renal malabsorption of tryptophan

Carcinoid syndrome

Overproduction of serotonin that causes diversion of  tryptophan from NAD+ Pathway

Vitamin B6 deficiency

Defective kynureninase pathway

Maize rich diet

Niacin is in unavailable niacytin form

Jowar diet (Sorghum)

Increase leucine content inhibit QPRTase enzyme

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Deficiency State

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came to the ER with a history of RTA. A fracture shaft of the left femur was diagnosed based on X-ray and examination findings. On the OT table, the patient suddenly developed facial swelling, and oxygen saturation dropped to 85%. Which of the following could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Sudden development of facial swelling and a drop in oxygen saturation may be due to anaphylaxis. Antibiotics are common causes of anaphylaxis during anesthesia.

Anaphylaxis causes mast cell degranulation, vasodilation, and secondary facial swelling and desaturation due to laryngeal edema. It can be prevented by a proper history of any allergy to common agents like antibiotics and latex. It can be avoided by giving a test dose of anesthetic and antibiotics prior to administering it in OT.

Other options do not explain the occurrence of facial swelling.

A fat embolism occurs 24-48 hours after fracture, unlike on the same day as in this case. It can cause a drop in saturation by blocking perfusion in the pulmonary vasculature.

Spinal cord injury might go unnoticed in a polytrauma patient, compression of the spinal cord might as well cause difficulty in breathing and secondary drop-in saturation of O2.

Sepsis can cause distributive shock and drop in saturation secondary to inadequate perfusion but it doesn't develop suddenly on the OT table. Thus a high level of suspicion is needed and monitoring is done to prevent sepsis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who came for trekking in the Himalayas was brought to you by his friends. He had consumed some herb that looked like horse-radish (mooli ) that was offered by a local quack. The patient is staggering as he tries to walk and feels numbness in the skin. Eye findings reveal alternate miosis and mydriasis. Prompt primary treatment is administered but the patient succumbs a few hours later. Which of the following poisons is implicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of aconite poisoning.

Aconite grows in the Himalayas and is a potent poison causing numbness followed by tingling, hippus (alternate miosis-mydriasis), and death due to cardiovascular or respiratory collapse. Its root resembles a horse-radish and tastes sweet, hence, there is a risk of accidental poisoning. The active principle is an alkaloid called aconitine.

Other options:

  • Nerium odorum, commonly called kaner may also cause accidental poisoning. It causes muscle twitching and spasm rather than paralysis. It causes pupil dilation rather than a hippus. 
  • Croton tigillum, commonly known as Jamal Gota, causes severe gastrointestinal irritation and purging with vomiting. It may also cause abortion.
  • Strychnus curare is a spinal poison causing paralysis when introduced into the bloodstream. It causes nothing if ingested.

questions.text: A patient came to the ER with a history of RTA and blood loss. A whole blood transfusion was to be undertaken. Blood samples were collected and were sent for typing. Meanwhile, 1 unit O-negative blood was transfused along with 5% dextrose in water. The patient was later known to be of AB positive blood group. The patient develops reddening of urine that stays as such after centrifugation as shown below. Which of the following might be the possible cause?

choices.text: The donor blood has anti-Rh antibodies, which lyse the recipient RBCs
The donor blood has anti-A, anti-B antibodies, which lyse the recipient RBCs
The recipient blood has anti-O antibodies which lyse the donor RBCs
There is non-immune intravascular osmotic lyses of RBCs

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image of red-colored urine point towards a diagnosis of hemoglobinuria alone without a history of transfusion reactions.

Hemoglobinuria alone without other symptoms of hemolytic transfusion reaction (i.e., fever, chills, urticaria, flank pain) might be due to osmotic lysis of RBCs. It might have been due to co-administration with 5% dextrose. 

In case of hematuria, RBCs settle down on centrifugation. But in case of hemoglobiuria, this doesn't happen and therefore we see uniformly red urine as in the image above.

Other options:

Rh blood group system doesn't follow Landsteiner's 2nd law (presence of antibody in plasma if the corresponding antigen is absent on RBC). Hence, an Rh-negative individual would have anti-Rh antibodies only if exposed to Rh antigen by transfusion of Rh-positive blood.

Hemolytic transfusion reaction occurs mostly due to lysis of donor RBCs by complement and immune-mediated lysis by recipient antibodies. Donor antibodies very rarely cause lysis of recipient RBCs, and this is one of the reasons, minor cross-matching is not undertaken before routine blood transfusion

The absence of A(NAG) and B (D-galactose) makes the blood group of an individual to be O type. O blood group just has a fucose base over which A  and B antigens are present. There are no anti-O antibodies, except in cases of Bombay blood group.

questions.text: An unvaccinated child comes to OPD with complaints of 3 weeks of worsening cough. The paroxysms of cough end with a high-pitched inspiration and are precipitated by cold air and cold liquids. The organism causing the above disease can be cultured on which medium?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture points towards a diagnosis of pertussis/whooping cough caused by bordetella pertussis which can be cultured on the Bordet-Gengou medium.

Whooping cough derives its name from the inspiratory whoop at the end of a coughing bout. The disease courses over 3 phases after an incubation period of 2 weeks:

  • Catarrhal - lasts for 1-2 weeks and consists of cough, coryza, and nasopharyngeal secretions.
  • Paroxysmal - lasts for 2-6 weeks and consists of worsening paroxysms of productive whooping cough. It becomes more frequent and ends with vomiting. 
  • Convalescent - Intensity and frequency of cough decrease over 4 weeks.

The diagnosis is made on clinical grounds. A specific diagnosis can be done by isolation of the organism from a nasopharyngeal swab taken in the first two phases, and cultured on Bordet-Gengou medium.

Management involves antibiotic therapy and supportive care. The incidence of pertussis has decreased significantly after widespread vaccination. 

Other conditions with prolonged cough include adenoviral infections, reactive airway disease, foreign body in the airway.

Other options:

  • Potassium telluride agar - used for the culture of corynebacterium diphtheria.
  • Wilson Blair medium -used for the culture of salmonella.
  • Ghee broth - used for culture of yersinia

questions.text: All of the following causes of hypocalcemia are associated with increased parathyroid hormone levels except?
questions.solution:
Hypomagnesemia associated with hypocalcemia does not have increased PTH (parathyroid hormone) levels.

Magnesium is required for PTH secretion, hence if magnesium levels are very low, PTH might not be secreted adequately, causing a fall in calcium levels.

Hypocalcemia not responding to therapy should be checked for hypomagnesemia, and magnesium should be supplemented.

Other options:

Vitamin D deficiency causes defective calcium absorption leading to hypocalcemia, which in turn causes PTH secretion.

Pseudo-hypoparathyroidism is an inherited condition with high PTH levels which is unable to act on its receptors.

The hungry bone syndrome refers to continued bone formation (due to compensated increase in calcitonin) and sudden decrease in bone resorption (due to fall in PTH levels). It is seen after parathyroidectomy done for hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: An athlete friend of yours and you join the gym on day 1 of the new year. Both are of equal height, weight, and same ethnicity. Both buy a smartwatch to monitor your heart rate and calorie consumption. Just before and after a similar exercise, both check their heart rates in the smartwatch. Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Both have similar increase in heart rate after the exercise
Both have similar resting heart rate
The heart rate of athlete increases more than you
The heart rate of athlete increases less than you

questions.solution:
Trained athletes have a lower heart rate both at rest and after any given level of exercise to a person of similar built.

This is because maximal cardiac output and maximal oxygen extraction increase with training. Cardiac output increases with training, hence, required blood supply can be obtained at a lesser heart rate. The athletes also have a bigger heart due to remodeling.

There is lesser heart rate at rest as the cardiac output is maintained by achieving more stroke volume.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with a swelling on the back of his forearm as shown in the image below. He reported it to be growing in size and found it cosmetically unacceptable. On examination, the slip sign was positive. It was removed by a resident doctor and sent for a histopathology examination. The content within the tumor is best stained by?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image point to a diagnosis of lipoma. It's a tumor of mature adipocytes and is stained by sudan black B.

Lipomas are one of the commonest benign soft tissue tumors of adult. They arise in the subcutaneous tissue of limbs or trunk. They are soft, mobile and generally painless. Slip sign is a clinical sign to demonstrate the mobility of the tumor in the subcutaneous plane. They are treated by simple excision.

Liposarcomas are their malignant counterparts, with multiple recurrences unless adequately excised.

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a gun-shot wound. He has a BP of 90/50 mm Hg and his heart sounds are not audible on auscultation. Another examination finding would be noted in which of the following structures to complete the triad of cardiac tamponade?
questions.solution:
The triad of cardiac tamponade is known as Beck's triad that includes hypotension, elevated JVP, and absent/muffled heart sounds. The component missing in the above scenario is the jugular venous pressure (JVP), which is ideally examined in the internal jugular vein (IJV).

IJV lies near to the anterior of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. It should be examined in good light at 45° of tilt. It reflects the right atrial pressure unless the superior vena cava (SVC) is obstructed. 

The external jugular vein might also show distention in cardiac tamponade but it should not be used for measuring JVP as it can be compressed as it passes under the clavicle.

Note: if the question mentions decreased air entry or breath sounds on one or both sides, pneumothorax may be suspected.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to OPD  with abrupt onset of fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood counts showed a decrease in platelets and RBCs. Bone marrow and peripheral blood smear showed cells as given below. Immunophenotyping revealed the presence of  CD79a+, CD19+, and CD20+. The cells of origin for these neoplastic cells are?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing lymphoblasts are suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The cells of origin for these neoplastic cells are precursor B lymphoblasts.

ALL is more common in childhood with a peak incidence around 3-5 years of age. The child had symptoms related to bone marrow suppression including anemia, and fever secondary to infections. These infections are due to neutropenia and generalized lymphadenopathy, indicating the effect of neoplastic infiltration. Hepatosplenomegaly points towards extra-medullary hematopoiesis.

Microscopy reveals lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scanty agranular cytoplasm along with B cell markers like CD79a, CD19, and CD20.

Other options:

Option B: Precursor erythroblasts are cells of myeloid lineage that will have myeloid markers like CD 33, and CD34. Though ALL and AML both have an abrupt onset of presentation and may be difficult to distinguish morphologically. Immunophenotype features will distinguish them. 

Option C: Germinal center B cells will give rise to follicular lymphoma, DLBCL(Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma), or Burkitt lymphoma with characteristic appearances. Moreover, these will have positive CD10 as a marker of the germinal center.

Option D: Thymic origin T-cells will show the presence of T-cell markers.
